Name: Taking the Gembloux Gap: A Pint Sized Campaign for Chain of Command
Description:
Taking the Gembloux Gap is a Pint-Sized campaigns for Chain of Command, designed to be played using the campaign handbook At the Sharp End.

A twenty-eight page PDF, Taking the Gembloux Gap contains an overview of the events of May 1940. as the German panzers rushed across Belgium, to be met by French troops advancing to assist their neighbours as part of ‘Plan D’.  If the German armour can break through at Gembloux, the flank of the entire B.E.F. is turned and the road to the sea lies open.

This campaign focusses on the critical actions of the 15th of May as the French 110e Regiment d’Infanterie attempts to stem the tie of 3 Panzer Division spearheaded by 3 Schützen Regiment.  This campaign is designed to be used with the Blitzkrieg 1940 Handbook.

The campaign is a total of five game tables with the duration running between five and nine games.  Briefings are provided for both sides, along with measurable objectives, period maps, force and support option listings and everything you need to play this campaign through to its conclusion.

Like all of our Pint-Sized campaigns, this PDF is available for the price of a pint in our local pub.  We’re sure that you’ll agree, that is great wargaming value!

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Pint Sized Campaigns for Chain of Command

Name: Hoops
Description:
Hoops is a card and dice possession-by-possession replay basketball game using actual professional player statistical data as its basis. You’ll find just about anything you see in an NBA game occur on your tabletop…clutch players making great plays in the final seconds, big men disrupting shots, lockdown defenders creating havoc on the defensive end, and great athletes generating points on the fastbreak.

—description from the designer

Name: Spies Race to Berlin, A Game of War
Description:
Spies Race to Berlin, A Game of War is a board game produced just prior to or at the beginning of World War Two. The large board (74 x 49 cm) shows Germany and surrounding countries. Austria and Czechoslovakia have been absorbed into Germany. The free state of Danzig, neutral Hungary and other countries (including Poland) are still independent.

Starting from London players follow various routes to Berlin, crossing numerous countries either by air, sea or land by the roll of the dice. There are detours, delays and short cuts and players throw again on a 6. The first to reach Berlin on the exact throw of the dice is the winner.

—user summary

Name: Board Royale: The Island – Military Expansion Pack
Description:
Guns, weapons and explosions! A lot of new toys to wreck havoc! Even some experimental tech in to the mix! This military grade expansion pack bring more options to eliminate your opponents. But beware! It is as easy to die as easy to kill!
Military expansion pack keeps the simple setup and mechanics of original game play and gives 80 new cards to give you more options and fun.

—description from the publisher

Name: Board Royale: The Island – Disasters Expansion Pack
Description:
A deserted island is a dangerous place. It is hard to survive even without other players trying to kill you. So be prepared to face the wrath of Mother Nature!
This 60 card expansion pack gives extra flavor of being on a wild and dangerous island. It even has an optional game mode where every player works together to survive!

—description from the publisher

Name: The Great Fire of London 1666: 2-Player Expansion
Description:
In this 2 player expansion, each player owns two colours of house, scoring for the surviving houses in both colours as well as for objectives and fires extinguished.

They must not only play against each other but also contend with movements of the fire and the trained bands that are outside the control of either player.

Will you save London or watch it burn?

—description from the publisher

Name: Board Royale: The Island – Skills Expansion Pack
Description:
You may be on a deserted island but at least you know things, things that can help you to survive. Take one out of seven personas and become more ready to handle what island and other players can throw at you!
This pack comes with 56 cards to give your game more depth then ever before. Be a scavenger, medic even a diplomat to find your way up to the top!

—description from the publisher

Name: Thorngate Tower
Description: An adventure-style tile and dice drafting game, where players compete to satisfy the leaders and stragglers of Thorngate. Players ascend an abandoned tower filled with demonic creatures in this post-apocalyptic fantasy-style game in order to demonstrate that they are worthy of representing the leaders of Thorngate out in the wilderness. Defeating creatures rewards players with faction points, moving them up 1 of 3 tracks. These will then award end-game victory points, depending on which leaders have been satisfied the most! Along the way players will obtain gemstones, artifacts, spells and more whilst also completing contracts to satisfy the local villagers.

Name: Board Royale: The Island – NSFW Expansion Pack
Description:
Dirty, naughty and bizarre. This is not Coral Island and we are not kids. We are adults. We have our own ways of fun! So get ready for a flavor that you've never seen! Did you get high on the island or lost in the realm? Who knows! who cares?
This expansion comes with 60 cards pack full of dirty fun, bad surprises and silly items. You will never know what comes next but can't wait either! There is also a party mode just perfect for this pack!

Name: Trick Mr. Troll
Description:
The elves just spent a warm sunny morning catching fish, turtles, and frogs. They need to return to their village on the other side of the river, but grumpy Mr. Troll won’t let them cross the bridge unless they pay him a toll! The clever elves agree to give Mr. Troll some of what they caught, but only if he can guess what it is. Can they keep him guessing long enough to sneak across the bridge or will Mr. Troll take everything?

In Trick Mr. Troll, 1-3 elves (usually children) work together to get across the bridge while Mr. Troll (usually a parent) tries to stop them. Every round, each elf hides a single fish, frog, or turtle token in their hand and Mr. Troll tries to guess what it is. If his guess is correct, Mr. Troll collects the token. If his guess is incorrect, the elf pawn moves across the bridge. Tension builds as each guess brings either the elves or Mr. Troll closer to victory!

—description from the publisher

Name: Ultra Deluxe 2D Arcade Mega Fighter
Description:
Relive classic arcade action with Ultra Deluxe 2D Arcade Mega Fighter, a two-player dueling card game based on 3-vs-3 tag-team arcade fighters such as Sharkfist, Slumberjack, and Tyranosorcerer. Draft from a group of fifteen fighters, each with their own abilities and evocative pixel art. Play "Button cards" to execute different attacks, and chain cards together to create insanely powerful combos — or mash buttons and hope for the best!

—description from the publisher

Name: Wow!スゴロク (Wow! Sugoroku)
Description:
Wow!ã‚¹ã‚´ãƒ­ã‚¯ (Wow! Sugoroku) is a Japanese roll & move game. Sugoroku is one of the earliest forms of boardgame in Japan.

This game is a simple roll & move game made for young children. The path is made from face-down triangular tiles, to give a varied snaking pathway. Players turn over the tile they land on and follow the instructions (in English). The first player to reach the end wins.
user summary

Name: どんでん (Donden)
Description:
ã©ã‚“ã§ã‚“ (Donden) is a Japanese abstract game for two players, similar to Reversi. The game has three wooden boards with 4x4 grids, and 48 chips marked on one side.

Donden was created through collaboration, born out of a project to see if something could be done using thinned wood from Sagamihara City. The game is packaged in a wrapped sleeve, made of Japanese paper. The chips are stored in the back side of the boards.

The three boards are arranged in a line. The players place two chips each from their supply in the centre, one player using the marked side.

Taking turns, a player either places a chip on the board, looking to attack as in Reversi, by flipping opponent's chips. Or a player may discard a chip and move one of the three boards around (a disturbance), thus causing an attack.

By taking an end board, for example, the player can place it at right angles, making an L-shape. This puts one of their pieces outside their opponent's, causing an attack.

The game ends when one player runs out of chips. The other player gets a final turn. Then the players get a point for each chip they have on the board, plus a point for each chip left in hand (not discards). The player with the most points wins.
user summary

Name: Lunar Echoes
Description:
Lunar Echoes is a cooperative game where two players will manage their resources and overcome obstacles during a space trip to the Moon and back, trying to gather the artifacts buried by a lone voyager many years ago - how many treasures can you find?

The game will progress through a series of phases and turns, and in each turn, the players will roll their dice and place them in the board and cards in order to manage their ship resources, collect treasures and avoid danger. At each new round, more cards will come into play, and if the players don't use their dice and resources to get rid of them, they will have to face heir hazards at the end of each round.

The game will result in a loss if any of these conditions are met:

    The players come back to Earth with no treasures;
    If any of the resources is depleted;
    If, at the beginning of a round, there are no cards left in the deck when they need to enter play.


If the players collect enough treasures and survive the whole trip, then the team won!

—description from the publisher

Name: Pippinzip
Description:
Pippinzip is a square board connection game for 2-3 players. Various sizes of boards are possible, from short games on a 5x5 grid played with pencil and paper, to longer games on a Go board (9x9, 13x13, or 19x19). 


THE BASIC IDEA:

The game begins with an auction phase -- a sort of mini-game of chicken (reminiscent of Unlur), in which an initially empty board is gradually seeded with a growing number of initial stones.  The auction phase determines who will play the role of "Pip" (using black stones) and who will play the role of "Zip" (using white stones).

After the auction phase ends and the roles are thereby determined, the players take turns playing stones of their color to the board.  Play continues until a winning condition is reached. (Draws are impossible.)  Pip wins by connecting any TWO opposite sides of the board via a chain of orthogonally-adjacent black stones.  Zip wins connecting all FOUR sides of the board via a chain of 8-way-adjacent white stones. ("8-way-adjacent" = either orthogonally or diagonally adjacent.)



IN MORE DETAIL:

There are two varieties of play, "Zipline" and "Pipline".


Pipline:

This is the standard version of the game. The game begins with an empty board and an "auction phase." In this phase, on his/her turn a player places 1-3 BLACK stones onto empty points on the board. (Each player has a free choice of whether to place 1 black stone, or 2 black stones, or 3 black stones on his/her turn.) Players alternate turns, playing black stones exclusively in this phase of the game, until one player on his/her turn says "Take" instead of placing any stones.  This taker is henceforth known as "Pip" and will play a SINGLE black stone on each future turn.  The opponent (i.e. the non-taker) is "Zip," who will play a SINGLE white stone on each future turn.

Immediately after "take" is announced, the non-taker (i.e. Zip) has his/her turn and places a single white stone, followed by a single black stone from Pip, then a single white stone from Zip, etc.  Turns alternate in this fashion until one player achieves his/her win condition (or until one player resigns). Zip wins by connecting all FOUR sides of the board with a chain of white stones that are orthogonally and/or diagonally adjacent; Pip wins by connecting any TWO opposite sides with a chain of black stones that are orthogonally adjacent.

Pencil-and-Paper Play: Pipline is the recommended version of the game for pencil-and-paper play (draw four vertical lines and four horizontal lines to make a 5x5 grid, as depicted here: https://boardgamegeek.com/image/5173760/cdunc123)


Zipline:

This is an alternative version of the game. To start the game, on each turn a player places 1-3 WHITE stones in the auction phase. (Each player has a free choice of whether to place 1 white stone, or 2 white stones, or 3 white stones on his/her turn.) Players alternate turns, playing white stones exclusively in this phase of the game, until one player on his/her turn says "take" instead of placing any stones.  This taker is henceforth known as "Zip" and on future turns Zip will play a SINGLE white stone per turn.  The opponent (i.e. the non-taker) is known as "Pip." On future turns, Pip will play TWO black stones per turn, with the following restriction:  Pip's second black stone of a given turn is NOT allowed to be placed orthogonally adjacent to the first black stone of the turn. (Placing two diagonally adjacent black stones in the same turn IS allowed. Also, note that in the extremely rare case where ALL remaining empty cells are orthogonally adjacent to first black stone, the second black stone is forfeited.)

Immediately after "take" is announced, the non-taker (i.e. Pip) has his/her turn and plays two black stones, followed by a single white stone played by Zip, then two black stones from Pip, then a single white stone from Zip, etc.  Turns alternate in this fashion until one player achieves his/her win condition (or until one player resigns).  Zip wins by connecting all FOUR sides of the board with a chain of white stones that are orthogonally and/or diagonally adjacent; Pip wins by connecting any TWO opposite sides with a chain of black stones that are orthogonally adjacent.

"Freestyle" Variant: For variety you can play Zipline with free placement for Pip's two black stones, that is, with no ban on orthogonally adjacent placements in the same turn.

Three-Person Pippinzip: The Zipline version of Pippinzip can also be played as a 3 player game.  In 3 player Zipline, the taker plays as Zip and the two non-takers play as a single Pip team.  Each non-taker plays a single black stone on his/her turn, for a total of two black stones for Pip for every one white stone for Zip.  Roles are determined in the auction phase using the same process described for 3 player Unlur in this thread: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1706872/unlur-three-people.



MISCELLANEOUS NOTES


     Before the game, players should agree whether to place stones on the intersections of the game board grid (as in Go) or alternatively, place stones within the cells of the game board grid.  Either mode of play is fine; it is a matter of personal choice.  



     The board starts out empty.



     Placement must always be to an EMPTY intersection or cell (depending on which mode was agreed before the start of the game).  There is no capture or displacement of enemy stones in Pippinzip.



     Once placed, stones never move.



     If during the auction phase, a player creates the win condition for the color being used in the auction phase, then that player wins the game.  (However, this won't happen if both players play competently!)




-description from designer

Name: Battle of Legends: Print & Play Edition
Description:
A board game of ancient-medieval battles between two armies consisting of famous historical units such as: Roman legionary, English longbowman, European knight, etc., each having different moving, attacking, defending abilities and special skills.

You must position them strategically across the battlefield to best coordinate your attacks and to apply some combat tactics such as oblique formation, outflanking, hit & run, shield wall, etc...

—description from the designer

Name: Don't Let the Wolves Eat Our Baby!
Description:
On a blizzard ridden night, a family traveling home slides off a mountain road. Their car is seemingly stuck in an embankment. Preparing to wait it out, a pack of wolven Berserkers appear out of the falling snow. Are these crazed people? Or becoming wolves? Or worse wolves becoming man? One thing is certain, the family is now the prey, and must escape! As the beasts descend upon them a desperate cry is heard, “DON’T LET THE WOLVES EAT OUR BABY!”

Players will play as either a Hunted family or wolven Berserkers. The Berserkers must destroy each member of the family. A single family member must escape the North end of the map, while hidden to survive.

"Don't Let the Wolves Eat Our Baby!" is a tactical hex and standee game with each standee representing an individual character. Characters have sheets with some individual stats related to speed, strength and will to live. In the short game, the family can win if any of them escape the north end of the map while hidden.

GAME COMIC CREATED BY CHARLIE FOGEL!

Note: Don't Let the Wolves Eat Our Baby! is a FANGORIA MAGAZINE EXCLUSIVE. It was made for their Winter 2019 issue. And all files can be downloaded from their website as a Print and Play:

It is also the 4th game featured in our "Halloween Nightmares Horrorgame Magazine" series. A game magazine dedicated to Halloween and the Horrorgame genre.

Players will need to xerox elements and provide two D6 and pencils to play this game.

Name: Village Attacks: Convention Exclusive Organised Play Pack
Description:
The Convention Exclusive Organised Play Packs were available to purchase at Grimlord Games booths or their website during conventions. These packs contain:

     10 new missions
     Printed copies of all crossover material for Dark Gate Games' Dark Ritual

Name: Almansa 1707: De los Austrias a los Borbones
Description:
At three o'clock in the afternoon of April 25, 1707, in the fields of Almansa, the differences between the European powers fighting, when Carlos II died without descent, were resolved by the succession to the throne of Spain.

A Bourbon army of 24,000 soldiers, faced an Australian army of 17,000. Spanish, French, Dutch, English and Portuguese soldiers, among others, fought defending the interests of their dynasties.

The Spanish War of Succession brought about the end of the reign of the Austrias in Spain, giving way to the Bourbons. Undoubtedly, one of the decisive battles of the History of Spain and the History of Europe. A war that, due to the extensive conflict, could have been considered the First World War.
With this work a new series begins, "Battles of the History of Spain", where we will analyze different periods of our history.

Our works occupy an unpublished plot in the field of history publications. An innovative design that will make the history lover enjoy, alone or in company.

The HISTORICAL NOTEBOOK introduces you to the battle, with a broad description of the time.
The model has figures with a base and planes, designed with materials that ensure its stability.
RECREATION is based on a coordinate system and a guide. Move the figures, relive the facts and study the battle from a bird's eye view.
In addition, you can "change the events" with a HISTORICAL SIMULATION GAME.

—description from the publisher (translated)

A las tres de la tarde del 25 de abril de 1707, en los campos de Almansa, se dirimieron las diferencias entre las potencias europeas que luchaban, al morir Carlos II sin descendencia, por la sucesión al trono de España.
Un ejército borbónico de 24.000 soldados, se enfrentó a un ejército austracista de 17.000. Soldados españoles, franceses, holandeses, ingleses y portugueses, entre otros, lucharon defendiendo los intereses de sus dinastías.
La Guerra de Sucesión española provocó el final del reinado de los Austrias en España, dando paso a los Borbones. Sin duda, una de las batallas decisivas de la Historia de España y de la Historia de Europa. Una guerra que, por lo extenso del conflicto, se podría haber considerado como la Primera Guerra Mundial.
Con esta obra comienza una nueva serie, "Batallas de la Historia de España", donde analizaremos diferentes periodos de nuestra historia.

Nuestras obras ocupan una parcela inédita en el campo de las publicaciones de historia. Un diseño innovador que hará que el amante de la historia disfrute, en solitario o en compañía.
El CUADERNO HISTÓRICO le introduce en la batalla, con una amplia descripción de la época.
La MAQUETA dispone de figuras con base y planos, diseñados con materiales que aseguran su estabilidad.
La RECREACIÓN se apoya en un sistema de coordenadas y en una guía. Mueva las figuras, reviva los hechos y estudie la batalla a vista de pájaro.
Además, podrá “cambiarlos acontecimientos”con un JUEGO DE SIMULACIÓN HISTÓRICA.

—description from the publisher (translated)
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: かなコロン (Kana Colon)
Description:
ã‹ãªã‚³ãƒ­ãƒ³ (Kana Colon) is a Japanese word game using 18 dice showing hiragana (Japanese alphabet). The game has two ways to play. In both games, players roll the dice to get random letter patterns.

For 2-3 players, use the dice to construct words in Japanese in separate block formations.

For 1-4 players, use the blocks to build a crossword style grid.

The designer says the game is experimental.
user summary

Name: Lightning Reaction: ReLoaded
Description:
Lightning Reaction: ReLoaded is a party game that tests players' reaction speed--with a shocking surprise for the slowest player. 
To play, each player grabs one of the handles from the base. When all players are ready, someone presses the Start button in the center of the base, which activates a blinking red light and suspenseful and anxiety-provoking music. Wait for it...when the red light turns green and the sound stops, all players try to press their trigger button as quickly as possible. If you're the last person to hit your trigger button, you get an electrical shock. As an added bonus, if you hit your button too soon (before the center light turns green and the music stops) you give yourself an electric shock.

OBJECTIVE: To have the quickest draw and the best timing of your opponents to avoid the shock.

Lightning Reaction: ReLoaded differs from the basic Lightning Reaction game in that this version allows player to adjust a variable shock control on the machine--to determine whether the loser will receive a shock of low, medium, or high intensity (although still only provided by three AAA batteries).

Name: Action Mayhem Game
Description: To collect the six star tokens that make you a winner, you have to compete all sorts of action tasks - from pretending to be a kangaroo or touching your toes to finding a sock or grunting like a pig.

Name: Robot Run
Description:
A fun matching game for all the family. Players take turns to be the first to get rid of all of their cards by matching them by robot type, robot colour, or use their paintbrush card to change the colour in play! The winner is the first player to get rid of all their cards.

This fast paced game develops matching and colour skills as well as introducing first gameplay skills such as turn taking and social interaction. Players young and old will enjoy playing this quirky game!

—description from the publisher

Name: Font HUNT
Description:
Font HUNT is a Japanese game made in collaboaration with a Japanese font foundry, Fontworks Co. Ltd. In the same way that European language fonts come in different designs (Times New Roman, Gill Sans) and different styles and weights (Gothic, Bold), many fonts are also designed for the Japanese alphabet Hiragana. Fontworks produced a popular commercial font called ç­‘ç´« (Chikushi), which is then produced in various styles and weights.

The game uses a set of tiles which only show a single character ã‚ (A). The tiles are all varied though, because of the variations in the different Chikushi fonts used.

The game Font HUNT comes in three different foil packs. A pack holds 12 tiles with 6 different fonts.

Each pack can be used for the basic game, and each pack has its own game variant. The basic FONTHUNT (ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒãƒ³ãƒˆ) game requires players to identify specific tiles by describing certain aspects of the font. "Huh? It sticks out here?" "A little thick here?" "A little bent?" "A little round!". Players can co-operate to try to discover which tile is being described, or have tiles in hand and try to have the other players work out which they hold. The game is intended to be more of an exasperating fun exploration of the nature of fonts, than a competitive challenge.

ç­‘ç´«ã‚´ã‚·ãƒƒã‚¯ é’ (Chikushi Gothic Blue) has a blue badge, and the game Font IMPRINT (ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒªãƒ³ãƒˆ).
ç­‘ç´«æ˜Žæœ é»„ (Chikushi Mincho Yellow) has a yellow badge, and the game Font TONE (ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ³).
ç­‘ç´«æ›¸ä½“MIX ç·‘ (Chikushi typeface MIX) has a green badge, and the game Font MIMIC (ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒŸãƒŸãƒƒã‚¯).

In Font IMPRINT, players conveys the impression of a font by using similies: "This A looks like Asaoka!" "This A looks like Amoeba!" 
In Font TONE, players have to imply the font by use of the tone of their voice.
In Font MIMIC, players have to use hand and body gestures instead of words.

The packs are normally sold separately (quite cheaply), but the publisher has sold them at the Tokyo Game market in a bundle with a bonus set of new tiles.
user summary

Name: 10 to the Top: Addition Game
Description:
10 to the Top, the fast-stacking, tower-topping game of making 10!

Contents and summary:
Ten to the top is a simple arithmetic game featuring thirty firm foam dice with numbers or a star on four sides with different colored backgrounds and two opposite sides with a blank white side or copyright notice.

Summary of play:
Each player takes five cubes, setting aside extra cubes except for one.  Place the extra cube in the center of the table with the numbers facing right side up.
Players add cubes to the tower as quickly as possible to make a total of ten facing them.  Once they do, they call "Ten."  
Cubes cannot be moved once placed on the tower.
Players keep stacking cubes to make ten.  If all players are unable to make ten, take a cube from the extra pile and add it to the top of the tower then continue play.
If a player knocks down the tower, they take two more cubes from the extra pile, then take a cube from the extra pile and re-start a new tower.
To win, stack all of your cubes on the tower.
Alternate play:  Take turns stacking a cube instead of racing and be the first player to stack all of your cubes.

—description from the publisher

Name: Dumpster Fire
Description:
Dumpster fire is a fast paced, hand based, card game for 3 to 8 players. In it, players assume the roles of scandal plagued politicians each struggling to deal with their own problems while sabotaging their opponents' efforts to do the same.

The game consists of approx 100 cards, split into 8 general types which are differentiated by color. Some cards can be played alone, others only in combination as part of a larger play. There are also cards which must be played, and a class of cards (scandals) which cannot be played at all. Mechanically, the game uses a traditional turn order structure, but emphasizes cross-play, off-turn, and table-wide cards to keep all players involved throughout a hand.

Each player is dealt a hand of 8 cards (9 in a 3 player game) to start. The cards are then separated into playable cards which are held, and scandals which are placed face up in front of the player. At the start of their turn the player draws a card from the deck, and can make a single play. The effects of cards vary but typically involve giving cards to another player or forcing them to draw. In many cases the target of the play can attempt to defend or retaliate with cards of their own, and there are even cards that allow intervention by otherwise uninvolved players. The emphasis on cards being drawn and given rather than discarded leads to escalating plays as the hand continues, and due to the number of cards changing hands, the players' prospects and opportunities change rapidly.

Victory is awarded to the first player to get rid of all their cards, and is determined on a per-hand basis, or across a series of hands using card scoring.

-description from publisher

Name: ¡Espana!: For Chain of Command
Description:
¡Espana! contains all of the lists for the conflict which tore Spain apart between the years of 1936 and 1939 and still leaves its legacy with Spain today.  

The rules and army lists remain close to the original principles within Chain of Command, relying on reflecting the way in which the troops were organized and trained to fight. This provides us with some very different forces and  really gives us an insight into the strengths and weaknesses of the forces present. 
                           
 ¡Espana! for Chain of Command results in a game which is fun and challenging in equal measures.

—description from game introduction

Name: Egyptia
Description:
Egyptia is a roll-and-write using polyhedral dice. Each turn, players will simultaneously decide what resources to collect and what building to draw in their hex grid, constrained by the roll of the six shared dice. (If you can't afford a building, you can always draw in a burial mound, for a few bonus resources but no VPs.) Each of the five buildings has three possible scoring rules, randomized before the game for 3^5 = 243 different setups.

The game ends in a maximum of 18 rounds when all spaces are filled; sooner if any one player produces enough of one resource over the course of the game to reach the endgame section of the resource track. Players total points for all the buildings they've built and the builder with the most points wins.

Official description: As one of Egypt’s most respected builders, you have been selected by the Pharaoh to expand the land. Each builder is given their own plateau to develop. Producing resources will be critical to your success, but do not be too tempted by your ambition, lest you should unleash a plague upon your growing city. Manage your resources and plan your city wisely to become the best builder in all of Egypt and earn a coveted place beside the Pharaoh!

—description from the designer

Name: Legends of Lima
Description:
Legends of Lima is a tile-laying card game where players are competing to reach one of the world's largest lost treasures, the Great Treasure of Lima.

The game revolves around a valley at the center of the table where the treasure is reportedly hidden. Each turn players take up to three actions. Possible actions include drawing a card from the deck, playing a path card or moving your pawn. The first player to build a path to the treasure and reach it with their pawn wins.

Watch out! Ancient totems sprawled across the island give players special abilities with exciting twists.

The game takes place in 1909, after a large earthquake had collapsed the largest cave system on Cocos Island into a valley. It had been rumoured that the island's caves had been used by pirates for centuries to hoard their riches. Players take the role of famous treasure hunters that have raced to the island to explore it.

—description from the designer

Name: Friendly Fire Pack 12
Description:
A Smörgåsbord of Scenarios

Designed for the Friendly Fire Tournament

Friendly Fire Pack 12 contains eight scenarios, of which some featured in the Stockholm ASL Tournament 2018, and the complete set in the Friendly Fire ASL Tournament 2018, held in Rimforsa, Sweden.

Name: Ka Pai: Toku Wakapapa
Description:
In Ka Pai: Toku Whakapapa you trace the heritage of life between all generations. Connect the five ancestors with each other and wisely use the help of the special spaces to recite your own lineage.

The aim of Ka Pai – Toku Whakapapa is to complete your lineage by connecting the five ancestors through identical symbols. The rules for connecting the five ancestors are similar to the original game. The special spaces with an orange border helps you to connect your lineage with those ancestors.

—description from publisher

Name: Achtung, Baustelle!
Description:
Achtung, Baustelle! is a children's game for 2 to 4 players 5 years or older. It is about concentration and speed in finding the correct building machines to fulfill orders.

Each player has a set of cards featuring different building machines. Each round a task card is revealed showing 2 to 4 of these, and the players have to choose the correct set from their cards to match the task. The fastest player with the correct set gets the task card, and the player with most task cards wins.

—user summary

Name: Die Olchis Kuddelmuddel Knubbel-Knoten
Description: A game in the style of Twister, using a less regular playmat. Meant for children and designed with the Olchis franchise.
Families: Creatures: Die Olchis (designed by Erhard Dietl)

Name: Urban Op: Afghanistan
Description:
URBAN  OP : AFGHANISTAN Test Scenarios  and  Maps

These Maps with hexagonal grid are a prototype version for a module on fighting in the "green zones" in Afghanistan from 1979 to today from Urban Operations of Nuts Publishing.

The maps with white edges (to be cut) are 90cm x 70cm and geomorphic as well as the 4 side maps. ( pdf format to print with a professional for low price )

- A hexagon is 21 mm from edge to edge

- a hexagon - 7 meters

- You will need the basic game Urban Operations to be able to play and perform the tests

- The Afghan Specific Rules and Lands, Scenarios test ( 6 )  Playing Cards, Markers and Unit Stickers (France and Afghanistan) are available free of charge, following the procedure described in the .pdf file (Ref download UOA).

—description from the publisher

Name: パピプペポペロンチーノ (Papipupepope Ronti-no)
Description:
ãƒ‘ãƒ”ãƒ—ãƒšãƒãƒšãƒ­ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒŽ (Papipupepope Ronti-no) is a Japanese word game for 3 players only.

The game has decks of cards showing Hiragana for the the sounds Pa Pe Pi Po Pu and the word Ronti-no. Players have to get the right cards in the right order and say out 'Papipupepope Ronti-no' to win.

There is English on the cards, so the game is playable without knowing Japanese.

The designer apologises for an errata in the first edition rulebook.
user summary

Name: Up & Away
Description:
This is a game of drafting and engine building. Draft the most beneficial cards, avoid obstacles or roll the dice if you're feeling lucky.

Each player gets 8 cards, a character, an engine and places their aircraft on the race track. In turn order, each player selects one gear-card and places it face up on the table, into their engine.

Each card played has a pairing bonus. If the adjacent cards can pair with the card in play, then the pairing will activate exponential and you get the active ability to make adjustments on the race track every round. Then, give your cards to the player on your left.

Play continues until all players have played all 8 cards into their engine.

To win, build the right combos, select a strategy and race through the track for the most prestiges.

Name: Tempus Quest: Episode 9 – Surprise Attack
Description:
The crew of the Tempus find themselves in a liberation fleet assaulting a dynasty stronghold. The battle could turn the tide of the war, but it is by far the most dangerous mission they have ever attempted.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer

Name: Anthelion: Conclave of Power – The Chaos: Faction Pack
Description:
In war, some are neutral not because they want peace, but because they want more chaos.

The Chaos: Faction Pack is a 5 card mini expansion that introduces the Chaos faction into Anthelion: Conclave of Power.


Released in the September 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.
Families: Organizations: Game Designers of North Carolina

Name: 迷宮蟻巣 (Meikyū Arisu)
Description:
è¿·å®®èŸ»å·£ (MeikyÅ« Arisu) (ãƒ¡ã‚¤ã‚­ãƒ¥ã‚¦ã‚¢ãƒªã‚¹) (Labyrinth Ant Nest) is a Japanese game designed to help children with simple arithmetic.

Players are constructing an ant's nest by laying tiles to connect tunnels under the soil. Each tile has a number of paths, and each branch has a number from 1 to 9.

The players put a starting tile on the edge and a central tile in the middle of the next. Each player draws a tile and tries to place it such that paths join.

Players are trying to place tiles so that the connecting numbers add up to 10. If a player can do this, they say "Thank you! 2+8=10" (or whatever the sum is). But if a player cannot make a connection add to 10, they are not penalised.

The winner is the first player to connect their starting tile on the outside of the board to the central tile.

The designers suggest an alternate for children who cannot add up, so that they need only have numbers match when played.

Alternately, they suggest you play the game in a terrible windstorm.

Name: Chain Mail: A Problematic Pest – Adventure Kit
Description:
It's not every day you get to escort such a creature, but the higher the risk the greater the reward, right?

Get the creature to where it needs to go and keep it away from pitfalls despite its heinous longing to throw itself head long into danger.

A Problematic Pest is an Adventure Kit for Chain Mail: Adventures of Earthshine.

Goal: Return the creature to its owner.

This expansion includes:

     Quest: A Problematic Pest
     Map: Heart of the Chasm
     Monsters: Silver Robot / Temporal Spiders
     Treasure: Cavern Map



Released in the September 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.
Families: Game: Chain Mail – Adventures of Earthshine

Name: Look A Round
Description:
A simple family party game, based on the popular Kaleidos game system: turn over an illustrated card and look for something whose name begins with a random selected letter. The first to declare an acceptable word, wins the card

In the box there are 80 large round cards, illustrated with hundreds of objects and with a letter on the back.

Every time players turn over a card a new combination of objects and letter is randomly selected.

The first player to get a determined number of cards, wins the game.

-description from designer

Name: Obscure Battles: Cold War – Close Air Support Expansion
Description: Air Support Assets extension to the Obscure Battles : Cold war Game. Has over 30 new aircraft and about a dozen Helicopters used for close air support during the cold war.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: X Corps: The Somme 1916
Description:
X Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British X Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the X Corps, Lt. General Sir Thomas Morland. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

X Corps builds on the core rules from VIII Corps, the first game in the series, and introduces:


     The concept of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
     The German use of artillery in tactical defence and in support of their counter-attacks.
     The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
     The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.
     Balanced victory conditions for both sides.


The increased chance of the British winning reflects their greater success on the day. Having said that this game sees the Germans unleash the power of their artillery as the British penetrate the German lines and both sides engage in a brutal fight for the trenches.

Contents:


     Rules (12 pages).
     Set of colour cards (12 pages with 9 terrain, 33 German & 39 British cards).
     Set of printer friendly cards (as above but German & British cards are monochrome).
     Set of full colour card backs (1 page)
     Illustrated examples of play (11 pages)
     Quick start guide (1 page)


—description from the publisher

Name: Pike & Plunder: Wargames Campaign Rules for the Italian Wars
Description:
Pike & Plunder v 2.0 - Campaign Rules for the Italian Wars

Pike & Plunder is a set of card driven campaign rules for the Italian Wars and comprises a set of five high quality pdfs. 
During a campaign the decisive battles can be fought with any table-top rule set such as Field of Glory Renaissance, DBR, Maximilian v2.0 or Impetus...


     30+ page A4 rulebook.
     48 Campaign cards.
     36 Ruse de Guerre cards.
     1 map & counters.
     1 large map & counters.


—description from the publisher at Wargame Vault

Name: III Corps: The Somme 1916
Description:
III Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British III Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916. This, the third game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules. 
There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the III Corps, General Sir William Putteney. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


     British first use of "Smoke" & "Make Haste" across No Man's Land.
     British mines at Lochnager & the Y Sap.
     German "Intelligence" intercepts and the use of "Tear Gas".  


Key game concepts:


     The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
     The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
     The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
     The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


Contents:


     Historical introduction and set up information (6 pages).
     Set of colour cards (13 pages: 9 backs, 9 terrain, 34 German & 39 British cards).
     Set of printer friendly cards (German & British cards are monochrome).


—description from the publisher

Name: 鯖威張る・サーバー (Saba ibaru: Server)
Description:
é¯–å¨å¼µã‚‹ãƒ»ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ (Saba ibaru - Server) is a Japanese card game using simple mathematics. The title is a pun, Saba Iburu means mackerel, and 'server' in Japanese sounds like Saba.

There is a problem in the computer, not aliens, not a beautiful woman, no, it's a mackerel. A mackerel has got into the system and it must be fixed.

Players use numbers and arithmetic functions, to try to make the target sum in the shortest possible function.

For example, to reach a target of 38:
8*5-2 beats 30+4+4 beats 4*8+5 beats 40-4.
user summary

Name: This Hard & Calcined Earth: A card Wargame of World War II
Description:
This Hard & Calcined Earth

Set in North Africa during 1940-43 the game is a campaign level card game.  
It portrays the broad sweep of events and strategic issues surrounding the famous desert battles in a game that is different each time it is played.

The name is a quotation taken from the beginning of episode 8 of the famous 1973 Thames TV series "The World At War".

The game deals with all the complexities of the historical campaign yet is physically small enough to put it in your pocket and play it down the pub, on a train, or in the garden. 
The rules are simple to learn but difficult to master.

With THACE events affect the outcome of the game but you always have some element of control.

The game provides an alternative, feasible history of the North Africa Campaign every time it's played.

It is, in other words, a campaign in your pocket.

Contents:


     Rules & Historical Chronology including both colour & monochrome covers.
     Designer's notes.
     Set of colour cards. A4 version (8 pages with 11 terrain, 20 strategic & 21 operational cards).
     Set of colour cards. US letter version (10 pages with cards as above).
     Instructions for cutting out the cards.


—description from the publisher

Name: Revolution!  Politics during the French Revolution 1789-96
Description:
Revolution! represents the problems facing the French State between 1789 and 1796.

It is a game of intrigue which aims to recreate the politics of the Revolution from the reactionary Monarchists, through the moderate Girondins, to the radical and ultra radical Jacobins.  
At the end of the game the French Revolution will have settled on a dictatorial pattern of leadership: the very environment that resulted in Napoleon’s assumption of power.

The game takes place in the French National Assembly building.  Players represent one of three political factions each composed of a group of famous characters.  They must find solutions to the problems of state raised by this turbulent period whilst wrestling one another for political control.

Each political faction, and in the advanced game each character, has their own agenda to promulgate whilst simultaneously denying their opponents power.  Like all forms of politics power is exercised by a series of votes. Players may use debate, bribery, bullying and scurrilous accusation to win these votes.  To win this game you must be prepared to engage in all of these activities at some point.

—description from the publisher

Name: XIII Corps: The Somme 1916
Description:
XIII Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British XIII Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916. This, the fifth game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules.

There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the XIII Corps, Lt. General Walter Congreve. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


     British use the Livens' Flame Projector.
     British use, and mis-use, of mines.
     Germans have less wire & are generally weaker.  


Key game concepts:


     The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
     The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
     The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
     The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


—description from the publisher

Name: XV Corps: The Somme 1916
Description:
XV Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British XV Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916. 
This, the fourth game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules.

There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the XV Corps, Lt. General Henry Horne. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


     British have less heavy artillery.
     British mines at Tambar & Mametz.
     Germans have less wire & more redoubts.  


Key game concepts:


     The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
     The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
     The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
     The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


—description from the publisher

Name: MindMaze: Bits and Bobs
Description:
In Mind Maze players will be told a story and must figure out why and how the story happened by asking questions that can be answered with "Yes" or "No". The person telling the story can also choose to answer with “Not Important” if players start getting too far off track.

Mind Maze allows players to test their skills of deduction and investigation, and to get to the bottom of the mystery with as few questions as possible. Players take turns asking questions, and lose a point for every question they ask. Points can be gained by asking specific key questions which also help players to figure out the true version of the story. This encourages players to think carefully about the questions they ask and to work together.

Name: 銀河大国 (Regional Colonialism Wars)
Description:
éŠ€æ²³å¤§å›½ (ã‚®ãƒ£ãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ‘ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚º) (Regional Colonialism Wars) is a Japanese game of strategic conquest in space. The Japanese title translates more closely as 'Galactic Powers' and the designer uses 'Galapa' for short.

Players develop planets by constructing facilities, improving technology, and developing spacecraft. Victory points can be earned through construction of the orbit elevator, the status of spacecraft development, and the population settled.

The game of space exploration wars uses worker placement with an rondel action track. When the game starts, players focus on infrastructure development, such as building facilities on the home planet and developing and strengthening spacecraft while advancing technology. Then, players build a subspace transfer device and move to an unexplored planet to pursue exploration. However, this involves the dangers of space pirates.

Discovering planets and building orbital elevators can also give you victory points, but the most points come from the population of settlers on exoplanets. The most settlers on the planet will be awarded the total number of facilities built on the planet as victory points.

But runners-up will be given the final total population of that planet as victory points. This means players must balance the development of facilities with the growth of the settlements. Produce too many settlers against facilities and the other players gain. Judging this expansion is important and the designer says it gives the game high replayability.

The game was released at Game Market in Spring 2019. The designer found some errata in the rulebook, and gave out a free card to fix an error on one card.
user summary

Name: Blood & Plunder: No Peace Beyond the Line
Description:
Blood & Plunder: No Peace Beyond the Line

This 248-page book is a supplement to the original Blood & Plunder rule book.

It contains plenty of new content:

     units, 
     ships, and 
     additional rules. 


Please note that this book is not a standalone rule book, only an expansion.

—description from the publisher

Name: Tempus Quest: Episode 4 – The Degna Job
Description:
After making the right connections, the crew manages to secure a contract.  Now they need to equip the Tempus and make it happen.  Unfortunately, the Dynasty has caught wind of their operation, which is going to make things tricky.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer

Name: Tempus Quest: Episode 5 – Big Damn Rescue
Description:
Despite their best efforts, the crew of the Tempus find themselves toe-to-toe with the Dynasty yet again.  An outgunned, out-of-supplies outpost of liberators is rapidly losing ground to an invasion force.  Knowing they are the liberation's only hope of escape, our heroes prepare to take a stand.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer

Name: Complete the Atlas
Description:
Complete the Atlas, a.k.a. ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¯ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒ‰ (Blank World) is a Japanese game of world exploration. Set in Portugal in the late 15th century, King Afonso V enters into a trade agreement with Lisbon's great merchant Ferdinand Gomez. Instead of granting subsidies to explore, the agreement entitles Gomez to exclusive trade in the specialty products obtained from the voyages. Players become one of the admirals employed by Ferdinand Gomez, pioneering the wilderness, discovering unknown creatures and natural wonders, building harbors and trading posts, trading, and preaching Christianity. Players want to increase their fame and become the world's best admiral.

Proving that the world is round, a new world map similar to — but not identical to — the real world will be created. Initially the game board shows a large map of the world known to Europeans in the 15th century, with all of Europe being depicted along with parts of Asia and Africa. The rest of the board is blank, and players place land tiles as they travel across the seas. In this way, they literally complete a new atlas (rather than trying to mimic the actual globe), and the game will play out differently each session.

As players draw tiles and discover new lands, they also close off potential sea routes. Balancing the need to discover and the need to trade is one of the game's challenges. Building a church and propagating Christianity to a greater extent also increases a player's fame.

Name: Dark Maiden
Description:
Dark Maiden is a cooperative adventure games in which the players advance through 4 different sites (village, forest, mountains and finally the Castle of the Dark Maiden) completing the required points in each site, to face the final bosses of each site. The last enemy to defeat is the Dark Maiden.

On their turn, a player can walk 1 field and draw 1 card or run 2 fields and draw 2 cards. Afterwards, all cards of all players are resolved. The cards can contain dangers or opportunities, and also the enemies that need to be defeated. Battle is resolved by dice. Each time a site boss is defeated, players will advance to the next site, but so will the boss of the previous site who will now become a subordinate boss on the new site, therefore increasing the difficulty of each site.

Players win if at least one of them survives and kills the Dark Maiden before all the players' lives are finished. The players can decide on how many lives to start with to adjust the difficulty level.

Name: Skirmish Afrika: Fantasy Afrika for Skirmish Sangin
Description:
Skirmish AFRIKA

AFRIKA is an imaginary continent set in the modern world. This book contains 9 scenarios and all the background information players need to create forces (ORBATS) for each of the 14 countries and UN Peacekeepers, Private Military Contractors and Guerrillas.

This book contains detailed background on 14 new and original Afrikaan Countries. Within this continent, its countries have a diverse range of problems that includes everything from war-like aggressive neighbours to internal dissent and terrorism. At the same time these countries deal with the spectre of modern colonialism. This takes many forms including aid dependency, unscrupulous trade deals and arms supplies from countries as diverse as China, India, Europe and the USA.

This is not a standalone rulebook, players will need a copy of Skirmish Sangin to use this supplement.

—description from the publisher

Name: Plausible Deniability: Spec Ops Missions for Skirmish Sangin
Description:
Plausible Deniability   contains 12 Special Forces scenarios for Skirmish Sangin.

It includes 9 ORBATS of Special Forces teams:

     MARSOC
     SEALS
     SAS
     UK PATHFINDERS
     FALLSCHIRMJGER
     GSG9
     GROM
     SPETSNAZ
     RPIMA


and all the associated rules to run a Special Operations campaign using the Skirmish Sangin Rules.

—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Ragers: Skirmish Wargames Rules for the Zombie Apocalypse
Description:
SKIRMISH RAGERS is a fast paced set of skirmish wargames rules for the Zombie Apocalypse.

The hardback Kickstarter edition includes the supplements: 

     Medieval Mayhem, 
     Hollywood Havoc, 
     Zero, 
     Echo Delta and 
     Year Zero. 


This 200+ page hardback book has everything need to run extensive zombie-filled campaigns.

—description from the publisher

Name: Woodland Wars: Skirmish Rules for Miniature Battles in the 18th Century America
Description:
Woodland Wars is a skirmish-level wargame for two players set mainly in the forests of North America in the last decades of the 18th Century.

Aiming to cover the period ranging from the Franco-Indian Wars to the War of Independence.

The game is based on the Surival Heroes system, the new engine designed by Massimo Torriani already used in Arkeo Obskura.

Name: Wild West Chronicles: Miniature Wargaming Rules for Gunfights in the Old West
Description:
Wild West Chronicles

This easy-to-learn and intuitive game system will soon have you simulating gunfights between outlaws, raids alone the Mexican border, Indian ambushes and many other other situations that are typical of the Far West.
These rules include army lists for desperados, Texas rangers, lawmen, outlaws, town-peoples and Indians.
Each model has a points value that depends on his skills and weaponry so you can create well-balanced scenarios that all the players can enjoy.
the use of the table has been reduced to a minimum and the whole system revolves around the addition and subtraction of six-dice.

There are three standard scenarios inside:

     the gunfight, 
     the rescue and 
     the ambush!


There is also a simple system to help you track the experience of your squads from one gunfight to another.

If you enjoy the wild west setting then this game for You!

—description from the publisher

Name: Final Assault: Battles in the Second World War
Description:
Final Assault allows players to field entire platoons of infantry and squadrons of tanks.

The system relies on you comparing the roll of one or more d10 to a reference value (e.g. if the Tactical Value is 7, you’ll need to roll 1-7 on the d10).

The game stands out for its attention to historical detail, and highlights the differences between the various weapons of the period as regards their range and firepower.

Players must pay attention because they can react to their opponent’s moves, but despite this an average game will only last a couple of hours even if you use four or five vehicles and fifty infantry.

Of course, we will also publish some free supplements on our web-site: two Army Lists (Americans & British, Russians & Germans), and another supplement with scenarios for friendly and tournament games.

Other exciting developments will follow too!

—description from the publisher

Name: The Great Puzzle Challenge
Description:
The Great Puzzle Challenge is a party game in which competitors vie to finish small 24-piece puzzles based on geometric shapes, scoring points for finishing first, second, or just getting pieces in the correct position.

—user summary

"What a triumph when you snap the last piece of the puzzle in place.  And the thrill is even greater when you've raced against the clock - and family or friends - and won!

"It's a fact, kids and adults love puzzles.  And they love games.  Now the entire family can share fun-filled hours doing both.  The Great Puzzle Challenge is a game - and a puzzle.  In fact, it's 24 different puzzles all rolled into one action-packed game."

—description from the back of the box

Name: Eternal  Samsara
Description:
China's first original trading card game.

In the Eternal Samsara game, you will summon aggressive war spirits, using powerful magic and vehicles. Compete with your opponents in time and space in the samsara of Eternity.
Each player should create a deck of 50 cards,include war spirits, magic and vehicles.The goal of this game is to make your opponent's lifepoint from 30 to 0. Each card in your hand can be place upside down as a magic stone so you will not be lack of magic.

—user summary

Name: Colour MY Kritters
Description:
Collect Kritters with splotches in three primary colours Cyan, Magenta and Yellow, and get hold of mixing bowls and paintbrushes to fill them with life. Use magic wands to change colours as needed to buy more Kritters, and add to your collection with bonus Kritters in secondary colours Red, Blue and Green.

Colour MY Kritters is a classic deck builder card game designed for younger players. You start with a few cards, and every round you have the chance to buy another card from the table. Cards have colour splotches (in three different primary colours, plus a wild card "colour"), and you use these to buy new cards. In the end you score the number of cards in each colour, but only for the colors you can supplement with a mixing bowl and/or a paintbrush. In addition comes bonus points on cards with Kritters in secondary colours.

—description from the publisher

Tabletopia: Play Colour MY Kritters for free on Tabletopia - you can try the game yourself and see how you like it :-) Find it there or on the official website (link below).

Print-and-play: A free PnP file can be downloaded from the official website (link below).

Kickstarter: A campaign for the printed edition of Colour MY Kritters was successfully funded on Kickstarter in December 2020 (link below). Late pledges will soon open so you can get your own copy even if you missed the Kickstarter.

Name: Beyond the Monolith Core System
Description:
Beyond the Monolith is a gaming system based on Batman: Gotham City Chronicles Versus Mode.

It's a two player scenarised skirmish miniature game in which each player control its characters using a command board.
On the command board, each character cost more energy to activate as you move left to right down the line. Once a character is activated, they move to the end of the line, boosting their cost to the maximum value should you want to use them again immediately, and decreasing the cost of the other tiles.

Beyond the Monolith aims to separate the game core engine and the universes in which the game will be played. For that purpose, the "Core Box" is  not a full game playable by itself but a core game set that include only a basic ruleset and all common components (dices, tokens, ...).

You will need to combine it with an "universe" that will supply the theme, the specific rules, the campaigns, the miniatures and tiles, the maps.
Monolith will provide two way to get universes :

     Universe Products : contains everything needed for an universe (ex : Conan, Batman : Gotham City Chronicles, Lord of the ring) 
     Second Life Products : provide extra components to play "Beyond the Monolith" with an existing miniature game universe [you will need to have or proxy this game miniatures to play] (ex : Zombicide, Cthulhu wars)

Name: Sarasota-Opoly
Description:
How do you make a game about the great city of Sarasota, Florida?

While it's impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Sarasota we could into this box. It's full of outdoor adventures, family attraction's, rich history, and of course... Myakka River State Park - a little something for everyone! Looking for a fun-a way to experience Sarasota?
 Here's a quick idea of how to play!

Buy your favorite SARASOTA properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun!

Get your game on!

Choose your token and advance to GO SARASOTA! You may soon be the Mayor... or out of the game for eating too much Lobster Carbonara from Marina Jack!

This is SARASOTA . . . and it's your roll!

—description from the publisher

Name: Operation Squad Modern War: Skirmish Rules for Wargames Set in the Modern Era
Description:
Operation Squad Modern War

Discover history by playing it.

These simple and intuitive rules will help you simulate the combats that engulf modern-day hot-spots like the Middle East. 
Inside you’ll find Army Lists for Americans, British and Italians; there are American Marines and Italian Bersaglieri, Republican Guard and Afghan rebels, for a total of eight possible armies! 
Each weapon and army has been given a points value to allow balanced scenarios that are also historically accurate.

The use of tables is minimal, and the whole system is based around a handful of six-sided dice. 
The rules also contain three scenarios covering typical missions: Recon, Finding documents and Freeing a hostage.

There’s lots of variety to give you hours of fun.

—description from the publisher

Name: Micro-Mini Basic Rules: An Ultra Rules Light Miniatures Wargame
Description:
Micro Miniatures Basic Rules is an easy to learn and rules-light tabletop miniatures skirmish game.

Micro-Minis is a rules-light miniatures gaming system intended to help new gamers more easily jump into the world of tabletop skirmish warfare.

The game is intended to be an inexpensive entry into gaming. Players can use any gaming figurines or miniatures they have on hand. The game only uses six-sided dice (referred to as D6 in these rules). Finally, gaming terrain and buildings aren’t necessary (but can add some neat flavor if you have them).

These bare-bones basic rules act as a great starting place for the system. It is intended as a completely open-ended game. Play with any miniature you want in any universe or genre you want. Mix up genres if you feel like. The point is to simply have fun.

This specific rulebook offers only the very base concepts and ideas for the game system.

It is also perfect for experienced gamers looking for an easy, fast, and fun beer and pretzels style game they can pull out on the fly without very much time to invest in setup and lengthy game times.

Later rulebooks will offer expanded rules and options as well as specific themes, genres, and unit types.

—description from the publisher

Name: Micro-Mini Advanced: An Ultra Rules Light Miniatures Wargame
Description:
Micro Miniatures ADVANCED Rules is an easy to learn and rules-light tabletop miniatures skirmish game.

Micro-Minis is a rules-light miniatures gaming system intended to help new gamers more easily jump into the world of tabletop skirmish warfare.

This ADVANCED rulebook included rules for purchasing weapons, armor, and items. Additionally, it includes new rules for Confidence and Retreats not featured in the basic version of the rules.

The game is intended to be an inexpensive entry into gaming. Players can use any gaming figurines or miniatures they have on hand. The game only uses six-sided dice (referred to as D6 in these rules). Finally, gaming terrain and buildings aren’t necessary (but can add some neat flavor if you have them).

These ADVANCED rules build on the FREE basic ones and act as a great starting place for the system. It is intended as a completely open-ended game. Play with any miniature you want in any universe or genre you want. Mix up genres if you feel like. The point is to simply have fun.

This specific rulebook offers slightly more ADVANCED concepts and ideas for the game system.

It is also perfect for experienced gamers looking for an easy, fast, and fun beer and pretzels style game they can pull out on the fly without very much time to invest in setup and lengthy game times.

Later rulebooks will offer expanded rules and options for specific themes, genres, and unit types.

—description from the publisher

Name: For God and King
Description:
For God and King is the second expansion for from Gilgamesh to Grant.

Badger with a quill is proud to bring you expanded army lists for the era of the pike and the arquebus.

New army lists and unit types allow you to represent the battles of this most bloody age, from Spain to Mesoamerica, and everything between, if one assumes we were heading east.

—description from publisher

Name: Emu-Hammer: 1920K
Description:
New From Badger with Quill, in spite of no one asking for it, Emu-Hammer 1920k.

A game about the famously failed attempt at wildlife control undertaken by the Australian government.

Things this game is not:

     Tested for balance.
     Historically or Zoologically accurate. 


Things this game is: 

     Pay what you want 
     Hilarious.


—description from publisher

Name: Radiant: Roster Expansion #1 – Welcome to the Arena
Description: This roster expansion contains three brand new heroes for Radiant: Offline Battle Arena. Enhance your game with a new teams, new strategies and a deeper, more challenging draft. Crush your enemies with Viggo the Disciple of Wrath, shield yourself behind the immovable Yokozuna Ichiro or call down the stars with Eos, the Herald of Rebirth.

Name: Basic 3
Description:
Basic 3 is a reprinted collection of 3 SPI wargames: Leningrad, Across Suez: The Battle of the Chinese Farm October 15, 1973 and The Big Red One: The Game of the First Infantry Division at the Battle of the Bulge.

Japanese language rules with 3 separate mounted maps and die cut counters.

Name: Bahamas: Raph Promo Card
Description:
A promo card to add to the game.
Rule:
Choose a player. He divides his Action cards into two piles. Choose a pile you take and leave him the other.

Name: Glorious Revolution
Description:
In 1688 William of Orange landed in England and ousted James II and his court. The more corrupt Chief Justices, lackeys of the old regime, must now escape England taking with them as much loot as they can muster to ensure a comfortable retirement in exile.

Each player takes on the role of a fugitive Judge, their agents roaming across England visit supporters and arrange for shipping of valuable donations to Carlisle ready for their lord’s escape into Scotland.

As the players collect these donations the forces of the Glorious Revolution sweep across England and Wales seizing
properties and detaining any agent or unfortunate Judge that falls into their hands.

A tactical game of greed and treachery as players gather loot, race for safety and steer the revolutionary forces onto their opponents.

—description from the publisher

Name: Doomtown: Hell's Comin' With Me
Description:
Gomorra is a boomtown on the edge of California’s Great Maze, that part of the coast that sunk into the water in 1863, creating a labyrinth of rock riddled with the super fuel known as ghost rock. Over the years, the town was destroyed time and again: by outlaws, demons, cultist fanatics, and more. Most recently, it was ravaged by the Fourth Ring Circus and the Sloane Gang.

In the aftermath, the deputies Xiong “Wendy” Cheng and Lucinda “Lucy” Clover left for greener pastures. Unfortunately, the pastures they chose were Tombstone, Arizona. They arrived just in time to see the conflict between the Cowboys and Earps reach its fever pitch.

On top of that, the mysterious Bayou Vermilion Railroad had also set up shop in town, and Tombstone’s been suffering its own supernatural problems.

And back in Gomorra, a familiar figure rides northward: Jonah Essex, a mysterious huckster associated with the worst events in Gomorra’s recent years. He rides toward Deadwood, Dakota, and if the town knew what was good for them, they would fear his coming.

—description from the publisher

Name: Slow As a Sloth
Description:
Slow and steady wins the race in Slow As A Sloth – the fun-packed quiz game where the aim is to be the slowest of them all!

A great family game where its the lowest and the slowest that wins the prize, players have to pick the answers with the lowest values to avoid accumulating points.

Designed for 2 or more players, Slow As A Sloth features 50 question cards where the answers are all designated numbers, and players should aim to accumulate the lowest scores possible to win the game. The game set includes 6 sloths to be used as player markers plus a felt game board to mark your (slow!) progress.

—description from the publishers

Name: Deluxe Advanced Squad Leader
Description:
Deluxe Advanced Squad Leader contains eight full-color, geomorphic 11" x 26" mapboards depicting both urban and countryside terrain, eight sheets of overlays to modify the terrain, and 38 scenarios designed for play on the boards.

Deluxe ASL is simply ASL without stacking. It features an enlarged 2.2" hex scale, making ASL more playable than ever. There is sufficient room in each hex to place over a dozen counters without stacking, making the game both easier and faster to play. Informational counters can often be laid alongside units to avoid obscuring them, and the need for some informational counters (like Covered Arc markers) is eliminated based on unit placement within a hex. Some players even use miniatures on these boards to increase their enjoyment.

Deluxe ASL includes all the boards and all the scenarios from the long out-of-print STREETS OF FIRE and HEDGEROW HELL. The eight original boards (a-h) have been repainted by Charlie Kibler and finished in the "tri-fold" style of Deluxe maps i-l from Winter Offensive Bonus Pack #9 (with which they are completely compatible). The original 18 Deluxe ASL scenarios are included, all updated and rebalanced as needed. Charlie has also repainted the original Deluxe ASL overlays (from the 1995 ANNUAL), four additional sheets of wooden and stone rubble overlays, and two sheets of new terrain overlays to provide maximum flexibility for future scenario designers. Twenty additional, out-of-print Deluxe ASL scenarios are also included, updated, and rebalanced as needed.

These features make this package attractive to all ASL players, whether they have been Deluxe fans for 30 years or never before got the chance to play on the bigger hexes.

—description from the back of the box

Name: De Bull Run à Gettysburg
Description:
De Bull Run à Gettysburg is a set of historical miniature wargame rules.

Orders to units are attributed by markers.

Name: Champions Combat System
Description:
The Champions Combat System is a rules engine used by a variety of arena combat board games, created by Dan Piché and published by Faceless Publishing. In games using this system, each player controls a champion and a number of associated reinforcement in battle. Players can battle one-on-one or in teams, and the side with the last champion standing wins.

Battles can take place in a variety of environments, each of which offers different challenges and opportunities.

The initial game release will include two boxes, Blood and Magic, and Into the Wild, with each game box containing six champions and their associated reinforcements, as well as two maps with customizable obstacles. The contents of each box can be seamlessly combined with other boxes to offer players  greater variety, and plans include multiple expansions to be produced later.

Instead of dice, the Champions Combat System™ uses a unique and intuitive card-based system to resolve combat. The use of cards rewards strategic thinking and careful resource management, while providing  each champion with a unique playstyle that captures their abilities and personality. The Champions Combat System™ provides strategic depth without sacrificing intuitiveness, and a new player can learn to play in only a few minutes. Of course, mastering each of the varied champions will take much longer.

—description from the publisher

Name: Dragon Ball Z: Smash Battle – The Miniatures Game
Description:
Dragon Ball Z - Smash Battle is a tabletop game of super detailed miniature superheroes and villains battling against each other.  Players fight with each other with special event cards, fighting skills, defending skill in an exciting contest of strategy.

This is a game designed for 2 to 4 players.  Each player takes control of his own faction of miniatures fighting in the famous Dragon Ball Z scene - Battle Arena.

GAME PLAY:
Build up your own team and game set up

4 Phases per Round:
PHASE 1. Event Phase - Dragon Ball Story Scenario
Draw an Event Card from the deck.  Each Event Card does not only tell a scenario of the DBZ story, but it also affects the characters in that round.  It might be a mission of collecting Dragon Ball, Saiyan turns to Great Ape, Ginyu Force Team sudden attack and more.

PHASE 2. Initial Phase - Prepare for Battle:
Set up the action sequence of characters.  The action sequence is critical and players have to apply their strategy in the next action phase

PHASE 3. Action Phase - Moving and Battling:
Each character comes with a character card which lists all of attributes, fighting skills and abilities.  Players apply their strategy along with the characteristics of each character in the combat of each battle.
Not only can players calculate the result of the battle by referencing the characters' card data with the rule book, but players can also apply the Augmented Reality (AR) app to get the battle result easily.

PHASE 4. Refresh Phase - Finalize the battling result and refresh for next round:
Finalize all the damages and results from the previous phase, and refresh the energy if needed.

Name: Flucht aus dem Büro
Description:
Held up in the office.
Friday afternoon and you are the last one in the office. Time to leave for the weekend. As you are about to leave you notice that the electronic doorlock does not functions and the door does not open.
Apparently your boss has a extra curicilar assignement for you and will only let you go when you have finished them. Not YOU! You'll find your way out of the office, but how?
With the puzzles in this game you will find out, if you can get out of the office. 
Using different information and materials, you and your teammates will have to find a way out of the office. It may sound easy, but tricky puzzles stand in the way of your freedom and time is limited. This requires ingenuity, teamwork and a clear mind.

Name: Tri To Win
Description:
Tri To Win is the thiathlon card game where players build their own board game to race on.

It is played in two phases. In the first phase of the game players draw and play one card per turn to build up their athletes’ skills, create the race courses, and a little bit of card and skill thievery. Skill cards are played face down next to your athlete, only you know what skills you have. All other cards are played face up, the Course cards are played along the corresponding course. Action cards are used to cause some mischief, with Action cards you can steal skills, cards, remove pieces of the race course and stop other players actions. Phase one ends when a player uses their turn to play the 'Start The Race' card at the end of the running course.

In phase two, players use their accumulated skills to race on the course they made in phase one. The Course cards are used as a board game with coloured player tokens that match each athlete. Add up all skills your athlete has gathered and these are now your movement points. Each player takes turns moving their token the number of swim points they have, then cycling, then running, stopping at each race transition until their next turn. The winner is the first player to make it past the finish line to the Gold 1st place position at the end of the running course. Keep playing to find out who comes 2nd and 3rd!

-description from designer

Name: Frenemy Dice
Description:
